Award.AbstractNarration:
The research objective of this Emerging Frontiers in Research and Innovation (EFRI) Origami Design for the Integration of Self-assembling Systems for Engineering Innovation (ODISSEI) award is to create a holistic approach, named photo-origami, to transform a flat polymer sheet into a mechanically robust 3D structure via a sequence of light-activated folding and deformation steps. This new manufacturing approach will be achieved by integrating shape memory polymers, photo-responsive compliant material, and optical waveguides into a smart canvas to enable sequentially folding. The research will develop methods that are applicable to several interdisciplinary fields including active materials, photomechanics, photochemistry, and optics, and thus can be exploited in a wide array of applications. The research approach starts from the establishment of the basic components and the corresponding mechanistic understanding, progresses to the development of multiphysical nonlinear design theory, and achieves the final goal of creating photo origami. Deliverables include a suite of active materials and their activation methods, multiphysical modeling and design tools, demonstration and validation, documentation of research results, engineering student education, engineering research experience for high school students, and dissemination the research achievements to the general public.

If successful, the results of this research will enable fundamentally new approaches to manufacture materials and devices with extraordinary functionalities. Example applications include new sparse materials with low weight but high strength or anisotropic properties, deep 3D MEMs with integrated electronic, RF or optical circuit elements. Manufacturing approaches from this research will offer the advantage of a flat initial state where functional devices can be easily placed and a final complicated 3D structure. Graduate and undergraduate students will benefit from a rigorous training at the interface between material science, mechanics, optics, and design optimization through involvement in the research. The research will also be tightly integrated into STEM education and outreach activities by partnering with the local school district to bring public awareness and to inspire K-12 student?s interest in STEM.

This project is supported in part by funds from the Air Force Office of Scientific Research.

ProgramReference.Text: GRANT OPP FOR ACAD LIA W/INDUS
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research objective of this project is to create a holistic manufacturing approach, named photo-origami, to transform a flat polymer sheet into a mechanically robust 3D structure via the interactions among light, polymer macromolecular structures, and mechanical deformation. This new manufacturing approach is achieved by integrating shape memory polymers, photo-responsive compliant material, and light patterns to enable folding.

This project established several innovative active polymers and robust approaches to achieve folding. First, a new group of shape memory polymers was created. These shape memory polymers could be fabricated by combining two existing polymers without relying on special chemistry and thus opened a new path for creating shape memory materials. In addition, the structure of the polymers can be controlled to exhibit new behaviors such as anisotropic shape memory behaviors. Second, this project established a new method for creating 3D structure by projecting a grayscale pattern of light and dark shapes on a thin layer of liquid photocurable polymer. This approach can be used to create complicated 3D structure by simply creating a 2D pattern in a PowerPoint file. In addition, the obtained structure is stable and stiff. Third, this project pioneered a new 3D printing concept called 4D printing where the 3D printed part can further shift its shape after 3D printing. Therefore, time is included into the shape forming process and becomes the 4th dimension. This new approach has the advantages of saving printing materials and time and can create parts with dramatic shape changes. Finally, this project developed optimization-based design approach to create origami structures. This enabled the design of folding parts to be based on rigorous scientific models, instead of designer’s intuitions.

The methods developed in this project are applicable to several interdisciplinary fields including active materials, photomechanics, photochemistry, and optics, and thus can enable fundamentally new approaches to manufacture materials and devices with extraordinary functionalities. Manufacturing approaches from this research offer the advantage of a flat initial state where functional devices can be easily placed and a final complicated 3D structure. This advantage can be exploited in deep 3D MEMs with integrated electronic, RF or optical circuit elements. Examples such as 3D electronics and direct 4D printing were demonstrated. This project also provided learning opportunities for all students and teachers, but especially those underrepresented in STEM through workshops, classes and camps. A curriculum was created where students and teachers could mimic the research in the research labs to create folding polymers.  This curriculum led to variations for students and teacher at all levels, from “Bounce and Tangle” a summer camp for under 10’s, to high school teacher training where the properties of the polymers were tested by creating 3D printed devices activated by the action of the folding polymers.  The camps developed in partnership with University of Colorado Science Discovery are still being offered even after the end of the grant period and teachers are continuing to use the curriculum materials developed by this project.  In total over 10,000 teachers and students had experienced these activities. Another significant outreach activity was the establishment of Geometry Point, an outdoor interactive exhibit focusing on the geometry of folding and the importance of visualization in engineering and mathematics.  Geometry Point is an extraordinary community project developing an outdoor exhibit in a local park named for a beloved Latino Community leader, Mike Romero.   The exhibit features many visualization and folding activities for kids and adults of all ages.  Designed to last more than 20 years, and now supported by continuing teacher training provided by the University of Colorado Center for STEM learning, its impacts will last long past this grant cycle. 

This Project Outcomes Report for the General Public is displayed verbatim as submitted by the Principal Investigator (PI) for this award. Any opinions, findings, and conclusions or recommendations expressed in this Report are those of the PI and do not necessarily reflect the views of the National Science Foundation; NSF has not approved or endorsed its content.

    Direct 4D printing
  • A variety of self-folding origami structures can be obtained by projecting a grayscale pattern of light and dark shapes on a thin layer of liquid photocurable polymer placed between two glass slides. This method can be used to create 3D electronics.
    H. Jerry Qi
    Copyrighted
    Hang (Jerry) Qi
    Origami structures from photocurable liquid polymers
  • Self folding arms was 3D printed by using the optimization design: (top) the shape from the optimization design; (bottom left) the experimental validation showing the 3D printed shape and the activated (or 4D printed) shape; (bottom right) the folded arms holding a coin.
    Kurt Maute
    Copyrighted

    Optimization design of 4D printed folding structures

POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The research objective of this project is to create a holistic manufacturing approach, named photo-origami, to transform a flat polymer sheet into a mechanically robust 3D structure via the interactions among light, polymer macromolecular structures, and mechanical deformation. This new manufacturing approach is achieved by integrating shape memory polymers, photo-responsive compliant material, and light patterns to enable folding. This project established several innovative active polymers and robust approaches to achieve folding. First, a new group of shape memory polymers was created. These shape memory polymers could be fabricated by combining two existing polymers without relying on special chemistry and thus opened a new path for creating shape memory materials. In addition, the structure of the polymers can be controlled to exhibit new behaviors such as anisotropic shape memory behaviors. Second, this project established a new method for creating 3D structure by projecting a grayscale pattern of light and dark shapes on a thin layer of liquid photocurable polymer. This approach can be used to create complicated 3D structure by simply creating a 2D pattern in a PowerPoint file. In addition, the obtained structure is stable and stiff. Third, this project pioneered a new 3D printing concept called 4D printing where the 3D printed part can further shift its shape after 3D printing. Therefore, time is included into the shape forming process and becomes the 4th dimension. This new approach has the advantages of saving printing materials and time and can create parts with dramatic shape changes. Finally, this project developed optimization-based design approach to create origami structures. This enabled the design of folding parts to be based on rigorous scientific models, instead of designer?s intuitions. The methods developed in this project are applicable to several interdisciplinary fields including active materials, photomechanics, photochemistry, and optics, and thus can enable fundamentally new approaches to manufacture materials and devices with extraordinary functionalities. Manufacturing approaches from this research offer the advantage of a flat initial state where functional devices can be easily placed and a final complicated 3D structure. This advantage can be exploited in deep 3D MEMs with integrated electronic, RF or optical circuit elements. Examples such as 3D electronics and direct 4D printing were demonstrated. This project also provided learning opportunities for all students and teachers, but especially those underrepresented in STEM through workshops, classes and camps. A curriculum was created where students and teachers could mimic the research in the research labs to create folding polymers. This curriculum led to variations for students and teacher at all levels, from "Bounce and Tangle" a summer camp for under 10?s, to high school teacher training where the properties of the polymers were tested by creating 3D printed devices activated by the action of the folding polymers. The camps developed in partnership with University of Colorado Science Discovery are still being offered even after the end of the grant period and teachers are continuing to use the curriculum materials developed by this project. In total over 10,000 teachers and students had experienced these activities. Another significant outreach activity was the establishment of Geometry Point, an outdoor interactive exhibit focusing on the geometry of folding and the importance of visualization in engineering and mathematics. Geometry Point is an extraordinary community project developing an outdoor exhibit in a local park named for a beloved Latino Community leader, Mike Romero. The exhibit features many visualization and folding activities for kids and adults of all ages. Designed to last more than 20 years, and now supported by continuing teacher training provided by the University of Colorado Center for STEM learning, its impacts will last long past this grant cycle.
